column1: Rome is the largest city in and the county seat of Floyd County
column2: Georgia
column3: United States. Located in the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains

column1: Rome was built at the confluence of the Etowah and the Oostanaula Rivers
column2: which together form the Coosa River. Because of its strategic advantages
column3: this area was long occupied by the Creek and later the Cherokee peoples. National leaders such as Major Ridge and John Ross resided here before Indian Removal.

column3: the longtime capital of Italy and also built on seven hills. It developed in the antebellum period as a market and trading city due to its advantageous location on the rivers
column4: by which it sent the rich regional cotton commodity crop downriver to markets on the Gulf Coast and export overseas.

column1: People of the Mississippian culture are known to have inhabited the area from about 1000 CE. These people are believed to have died off from disease brought by exposure to the Spaniards in the late 16th century. The Cherokee migrated into the Southeast and established themselves in the early 17th century.
Specifics before the Spanish expeditions in the 16th century are largely unknown
column2: but archeologists have found evidence of thousands of years of indigenous cultures along these rivers.

column1: Some debate exists over whether Hernando de Soto was the first Spanish conquistador to encounter Native Americans in the area now known as Rome
column2: but it is usually agreed that he passed through the region with his expedition in 1540. In 1560
column3: Tristán de Luna sent a detachment of 140 soldiers and two Dominican friars north along de Soto's route. They established relations with the Coosa chiefdom
column4: as they recorded assisting the Coosa in a raid against the rebellious province of Napochín
column5: in what is now known as Tennessee. Exposed to new Eurasian infectious diseases
column6: these mound builder peoples suffered high mortality rates
column7: as they lacked immunity; within 20 years the community was abandoned.

column1: The Creek emerged in the area
column2: one of the major Muscogee-speaking tribes. They occupied a broad territory before being pushed out by Cherokee migrating from Tennessee.

column1: The Abihka tribe of Creek in the area of Rome later became part of the Upper Creek people. They merged with other Creek tribes to become the Ulibahalis
column2: who later migrated westward into Alabama in the general region of Gadsden. By the mid-18th century
column3: Iroquoian-speaking Cherokee had moved into the area and occupied it. They had moved down from areas of Tennessee
column4: under pressure from settlement by European Americans migrating from eastern territories across the Appalachians.

column1: A Cherokee village named Chatuga was settled in this area during the late 18th century
column2: in the period of the Cherokee–American wars (1776–94) during and after the American Revolutionary War. The Cherokee referred to this area as "Head of Coosa".  Several Cherokee national leaders settled here
column3: developing plantations
column4: including chiefs Major Ridge and John Ross. In the 20th century
column5: Ridge's home here was preserved as Chieftains House. It has been adapted by the state for use as the Chieftains Museum and is used to represent the history of the Cherokee in this area
column6: especially Major Ridge.

column2: a high demand in Europe for American deerskins had led to a brisk trade between Native hunters and White traders. A few White traders and some settlers (primarily from the British colonies of Georgia and Carolina) were accepted by the Head of Coosa Cherokee. These were later joined by missionaries
column3: and then more settlers. After the American War of Independence
column4: most new settlers came from the area of Georgia east of the Proclamation Line of 1763.

column2: in response to a Cherokee raid into Tennessee
column3: John Sevier
column4: the Governor of Tennessee
column5: led a retaliatory raid against the Cherokee in the vicinity of Myrtle Hill
column6: in what was known as the Battle of Hightower.

column2: the United States and Georgia executed the Compact of 1802
column3: in which Georgia sold its claimed western lands (a claim dating to the colonial era) to the United States. In return
column4: the federal government agreed to ignore Cherokee land titles and remove all Cherokee from Georgia. The commitment to evict the Cherokee was not immediately enforced
column5: and Chiefs John Ross and Major Ridge led efforts to stop their removal
column6: including several federal lawsuits.

column2: most Cherokee took the side of the Upper Creek Indians
column3: who were more assimilated and willing to deal with European Americans
column4: against the Red Stick or Lower Creek Indians
column5: who lived more distant from the Whites and maintained strong cultural traditions. Before the Cherokee moved to Head of Coosa
column6: Chief Ridge commanded a company of warriors as a unit of the Tennessee militia
column7: with Chief Ross as adjutant. This Cherokee unit was under the overall command of United States Major Andrew Jackson
column8: and supported the Upper Creek. They were the part of the Creek who had adopted more European-American customs and were more aligned with American settlers. The Red Stick Creek lived in a more geographically removed area and held more closely to traditional Creek life. The Creek War played out within the US-British conflict of the War of 1812.

column2: European Americans discovered gold near Dahlonega
column3: Georgia
column4: starting the first gold rush in the United States. Congressional passage of the Indian Removal Act of 1830
column5: which fulfilled the Compact of 1802
column6: was related to that gold discovery and the desire of Whites to settle the land
column7: as well as President Andrew Jackson's commitment to removal.

column3: Georgia's General Assembly passed legislation that claimed all Cherokee land in Northwest Georgia. This entire territory was called Cherokee County; the following year
column4: the Assembly organized the territory as the nine counties that still exist in the 21st century.

column1: Rome was founded in 1834 as European Americans increasingly settled in Georgia. Founders were Col. Daniel R. Mitchell
column2: Col. Zacharia Hargrove
column3: Maj. Philip Hemphill
column4: Col. William Smith
column5: and John Lumpkin (nephew of Governor Lumpkin); most were veterans of the War of 1812. They held a drawing at Alhambra to determine the name of the new city
column6: with Col. Mitchell submitting the name of Rome because of the area's hills and rivers. Mitchell's submission was drawn
column7: and the Georgia Legislature chartered Rome as an official city in 1835. The county seat was subsequently moved east from the village of Livingston to Rome.With the entire area still occupied primarily by Cherokee
column8: the city developed to serve the agrarian needs of the new cotton-based economy. Invention of the cotton gin in the late 18th century made processing of short-staple cotton profitable. This was the type of cotton that best thrived in the upland areas
column9: in contrast to that grown on the Sea Islands and in the Low Country.

column1: Much of upland Georgia was developed as what became known as the Black Belt
column2: named for the fertile soil. Planters brought or purchased many enslaved African Americans as workers for the labor-intensive crop. The leading Cherokee participated in the cultivation of cotton as a commodity crop
column3: which soon replaced deerskin trading as a source of wealth in the region. The first steamboat navigated the Coosa River to Rome in 1836
column4: reducing the time-to-market for the cotton trade and speeding travel between Rome and New Orleans on the Gulf Coast
column5: the major port for export of cotton.

column2: the Cherokee had run out of legal options in resisting removal. They were the last of the major Southeast tribes to be forcibly moved to the Indian Territory (in modern-day Oklahoma) on the Trail of Tears. After the removal of the Cherokee
column3: their homes and businesses were taken over by Whites
column4: with much of the property distributed through a land lottery.

column1: The Rome economy continued to grow. In 1849
column2: an 18-mile (29 km) rail spur to the Western and Atlantic Railroad in Kingston was completed
column3: significantly improving transportation to the east. This route was later followed in the 20th-century construction of Georgia Highway 293. By 1860 the population had reached 4
column4: 010 in the city
column5: and 15
column6: 195 in the county.

column1: Rome's iron works were an important manufacturing center during the Civil War
column2: supplying many cannons and other armaments to the Confederate effort. In April 1863
column3: the city was defended by Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest against Union Colonel Abel Streight's "lightning mule" raid from the area east of modern-day Cedar Bluff
column4: Alabama. General Forrest tricked Colonel Streight into surrendering just a few miles shy of Rome. Realizing their vulnerability
column5: Rome's city council had allocated $3
column6: 000 to build three fortifications. Although these became operational by October 1863
column7: efforts to strengthen the forts continued as the war progressed. These forts were named after Romans who had been killed in action: Fort Attaway was on the western bank of the Oostanaula River
column8: Fort Norton was on the eastern bank of the Oostanaula
column9: and Fort Stovall was on the southern bank of the Etowah River. The Confederates later built at least one other fort on the northern side of the Coosa River.

column2: Union General Jefferson C. Davis
column3: under the command of Major General William Tecumseh Sherman
column4: attacked and captured Rome when the outflanked Confederate defenders retreated under command of Major General Samuel Gibbs French. Union General William Vandever was stationed in Rome and is shown with his staff in a photograph taken there. Due to Rome's forts and iron works
column5: which included the manufacture of cannons
column6: Rome was a significant target during Sherman's march through Georgia to take and destroy Confederate resources. Davis' forces occupied Rome for several months
column7: making repairs to use the damaged forts and briefly quartering General Sherman. Foreshadowing Sherman's Special Field Orders
column12: and any other materiel that could be useful to the South's war effort as they withdrew from Rome to participate in the Atlanta Campaign.

column2: Rome constructed a water tank on Neely Hill
column3: which overlooks the downtown district. This later was adapted as a clock tower visible from many points in the city. It has served as the town's iconic landmark ever since
column4: and is featured in the city's crest and local business logos. As a result
column5: Neely Hill is also referred to as Tower or Clock Tower Hill. In this period
column6: the city established its first public schools
column7: authorized by the state legislature in 1868 for the first time for all children
column8: with some designated funding. Schools were segregated and tended to have short sessions limited by funding. Freedmen had the power to vote under new amendments to the US Constitution
column9: affecting local politics. The abolition of slavery required new labor arrangements.

column2: Rome has occasionally suffered serious flooding. The flood of 1886 inundated the city to such depth that a steamboat traveled down Broad Street. In 1891
column3: upon recommendation of the United States Army Corps of Engineers
column4: the Georgia State Legislature amended Rome's charter to create a commission to oversee the construction of river levees to protect the town against future floods. In the late 1890s
column5: additional flood control measures were instituted
column6: including raising the height of Broad Street by about 15 feet (4.6 m). As a result
column7: the original entrances and ground-level floors of many of Rome's historic buildings became covered over and had to serve as basements.

column1: This statue of the Capitoline Wolf

column2: anti-Italian sentiment due to World War II became so strong that the Rome city commission moved the statue into storage to prevent vandalism. They replaced it with an American flag. In 1952
column3: the city restored the statue to its former location in front of City Hall.

column2: the effect of the Great Depression was significantly less severe than in other
column3: larger cities across the United States. Since Rome was an agricultural town
column4: food could be grown in surrounding areas. Rome's textile mill continued operating
column5: providing steady jobs as a buffer against the hardships of the Great Depression.The Great Depression was preceded by the "Cotton Bust" across the South. This reached Rome in the mid-1920s
column6: and caused many farmers to move away
column7: sell their land
column8: or convert to other agricultural crops
column9: such as corn. Farm workers were displaced
column10: and many African Americans left the area in the Great Migration
column12: including those in the North and Midwest. Cotton crops were being destroyed by the boll weevil
column13: a tiny insect that reached Georgia in 1915 (invading from Louisiana). The boll weevil destroyed many fields of cotton and put a damper on Rome's economy.

column1: While the Rome area was not as devastated as many big cities during the Depression
column2: many families struggled through hard financial times. Jobs were scarce
column3: and prices of food and basic commodities went up. The federal "postal employees took a fifteen per cent cut in pay
column4: and volunteered a further ten per cent reduction in work time to save the jobs of substitute employees who otherwise would have been thrown out of work." Among fundraising activities for the poor
column5: wealthier residents bought tickets to a show put on by local performers; the fares were paid to grocers
column6: who made boxes of food to sell at a discount price to needy families.In a private "works project" to provide employment to men out of work

column1: The city of Rome  commission-manager form of government was first adopted in 1918. The city's charter as approved by the legislature authorized a nine-member City Commission and a five-member Board of Education
column2: to be elected concurrently
column3: on an at-large basis by a plurality of the vote. The city was divided into nine wards
column4: with one city commissioner from each ward to be chosen in the citywide election. There was no residency requirement for Board of Education candidates.

column2: after the Voting Rights Act of 1965 (VRA) was passed
column3: the city amended its charter with approval by the state legislature
column4: reducing the number of wards from nine to three
column5: with commission members to be elected by at-large voting to numbered positions
column6: three for each ward
column7: with three wards in total. Candidates were required to win by majority vote
column8: with run-off elections between the top two candidates for each seat if no majority emerged after the first round of voting. From 1964 to 1975
column9: the legislature approved the city's 60 acts for annexations
column10: which mostly appropriated areas with white-majority populations.At the same time
column11: the board of education was increased to six members elected from three wards
column12: with two numbered positions to be elected at-large from the city for each ward
column13: A majority vote was required to win
column14: with runoff procedures to apply to the top two candidates if no majority was achieved. A residency requirement was added for the board members.

column1: This entire proposal was subject to review under the VRA; the city challenged the attorney general's authority to reject the annexation and electoral systems for each
column2: as plaintiffs believed the reduction in seats and requirement for majority ranking to win would dilute the voting power of the African-American minority. In 1970
column3: the city had a population of 30
column5: with an ethnic composition of 76.6% White and 23.4% Black. African Americans had been essentially disenfranchised for decades under the state constitution and practices since the turn of the 20th century.

column1: In City of Rome v. United States
column3: the US Supreme Court ruled on the city's argument that the attorney general had acted incorrectly in failing to approve the city's changes to its election system and its annexations. (The city did not seek preclearance of its charter changes to its election system in 1966
column4: nor did it get approval of its 60 annexations from November 1
column6: to February 10
column8: which were both required under the law.)

column1: The court upheld the constitutionality of the act
column2: including the prohibition of unintentional discrimination to mitigate the potential that a jurisdiction may engage in intentional discrimination. Because of these findings
column3: the court affirmed the lower court ruling.
